SENT.plain: In endemic areas brucellosis can present with clinical features of nearly any neurological illness
Meningitic presentation is most common, with patient presenting with either acute or chronic meningitis
Pseudotumor--like presentation is also documented and accounts for only 4% of cases of neurobrucellosis
Here we are documenting a case of neurobrucellosis with presentation similar to pseudotumor cerebri but with abnormal CSF

This highlights the fact that being a potentially treatable condition brucellosis should always come in the differential diagnosis of neurotuberculosis especially if there are atypical features e.g. pseudotumor presentation with abnormal CSF
